newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil changes tariff structure for car parts.
newsitem.headline: Brazil changes tariff structure for car parts.

text.p: Brazil Thursday altered some elements of its Car Industry Regime, raising tariffs on car parts and primary components, Presidency officials said.
The official said a decree signed by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso would raise tariffs for the rest of 1996 on car parts to 4.8 percent from 2.4 percent currently.
In 1997, the tariff will be 7.2 percent and in 1998 and 1999 9.6 percent, reaching 16 percent in the year 2000, the level set under the Mercosur custom union's common tariff list.

For primary components for the auto industry, the current 2.0 percent tariff will rise to 3.6 percent in 1996, 5.4 percent in 1997 and 7.2 percent in 1998 and 1999, reaching 12 percent in 2000, the officials said.

Brazil also reduced the grace period for "newcomers" to adapt to Brazil's Car Industry Regime to one year from three years. "The objective is to dissuade car part firms who only assemble. We want them to come to produce," private Invest News agency quoted Frederico Alvarez, executive secretary of the Foreign Trade Council, as saying.
